bibl.title: Letter from Horace W. Davis to Philip Showalter Hench, October 7, 1940

div1.p: Davis informs Hench that he will unable to attend the ceremony honoring Hench.

div1.head: Letter from Horace W. Davis to Philip Showalter Hench, October 7, 1940
div1.opener:
HORACE W. DAVIS
PITTSFIELD, MASSACHUSETTS
October 7, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Phil:
div1.p:
Here I have these two good letters of yours. I want to try to answer
them as fully and as plainly as I can.

First, there are a lot of things that are cockeyed about you, not the
least among which is this humble modesty. I would never have had
occasion to make the comment I made about Hutch's distribution of
degrees if he had confined his approval to Phil Henches. Truly and
sincerely, I know of no man on his way up that is more deserving of
such an honor than you.

In a like manner, I don't believe degrees should be given except to
people whose acceptance of the degree in turn honors the college award-
ing it. The system at Washington and Jefferson is, in my opinion, all
haywire. I have advocated for a long time that no degree be awarded
until the name of the candidate proposed together with all qualifications
be submitted to all the trustees and that a blackball would eliminate
the awarding of a degree. That is not the system. There is a committee
on degrees and the only time a trustee like myself gets a look in on
them is when I happen to be at a meeting.

I happened to be at the meeting at which your name was brought up. I
did not bring it up; but, as I have already inferred, there was no time
that I voted on a degree with more enthusiasm than that of yours. But
you see you are wrong again. I had nothing to do with the inspiring of
this honor.

The thing that caused my comment was the degree that Washington and
Jefferson awarded to that Donald Duck - Harold Ickes. I think politicians
are just like Indians. The only good ones are the dead ones. In other
words, all political degrees should be posthumous and personally I think
we will never get rid of the stench that that Ickes degree leaves in its
track.

I had wanted to be out at this Home-Coming Week and be present when you
spoke and were awarded your degree but it is going to be impossible for
me to be there. My distance from Washington and Jefferson makes it
very difficult for me to get there even once a year, which I have prom-
ised myself to do. But, unfortunately, due to a collection of appoint-
ments, it would be utterly impossible to get out there this month. So
consider me as present and approving in spirit although not in person.

If you, or you and Mary, come on to New York in connection with this
trip to Washington and Jefferson, do let me know. Perhaps I can get
the two of you up here for a weekend.
With best to both of you,
